content: Layered transition metal oxides (NaxTMO2, 0 < x ≤ 1) are considered one of the most promising cathodes for Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to their high theoretical capacity and operability. However, NaxTMO2 still faces significant challenges, including poor kinetic performance and low energy efficiency. Herein, in order to enhance the kinetics of NaNi1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3O2 (NaNFMO), topography control and component design were proposed: First, Cu doping (Cu-NaNFMO) was used to expand lattice channels and improve “flat sheet” of layered oxide, which synergistically enhanced transport kinetics of Na+. Second, Co coating (NaNFMO@Co) reacted with surface residue to form a fast-ionic conductor NaxCoO2 (0 < x ≤ 1), which inhibited interfacial side reactions and enhanced transport kinetics of Na+. Furthermore, the presence of strong Cu-O bonds in Cu-NaNFMO and fast-ionic conductor NaxCoO2 in NaNFMO@Co led to better electrochemical redox performance, the initial charge specific capacity of NaNFMO was increased from 141.5 mAh g⁻1 to 145.8 mAh g⁻1 and 144 mAh g⁻1, with capacity retention improving by nearly 10 % after 100 cycles. Furthermore, NaNFMO@Co improves ICE from 90.56 % to 93.57 %. With the improved kinetics, the DCR of pouch cells decreased, and the energy efficiency increased from 93.3 % to 94 % and 95.7 %.
Previous article in issue
Next article in issue
Sections.name: Abstract

content: In recent years, the continuous development of energy storage and electric vehicles has led to widespread use of Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) due to their high specific capacity, long cycling performance, and high energy density [ ]. However, the high cost of LIBs is a significant drawback, primarily due to the scarcity and uneven distribution of lithium resources in nature. Additionally, the recycling of lithium sources from spent batteries is challenging and inefficient [ , , , ], further escalating the costs. To address these issues, researchers have increasingly turned their attention to Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), which share similar charge-discharge mechanisms with LIBs. Both sodium (Na) and lithium (Li) belong to the alkali metal group in the periodic table, resulting in comparable physical and chemical properties. Moreover, sodium source is abundant, widely distributed, and easier to obtain, leading to lower costs for SIBs [ , ]. However, the larger ionic radius of Na+ (1.02 Å compared to 0.76 Å for Li+) and its higher relative atomic mass (23 g mol g−1 for Na vs. 6.9 g mol g−1 for Li) result in poorer kinetic performance and lower energy density for SIBs, hindering their widespread use in large-scale energy storage applications.

Currently, a variety of cathode materials for SIBs are under extensive investigation, including layered transition metal oxides (NaxTMO2, 0 ＜ x ≤ 1, where TM denotes transition metal), polyanion compounds [ , ], prussian blue analogs (PBAs) [ ], and organic compounds [ ]. Among these, layered oxides (NaxTMO2) has garnered significant attention due to the similarity in synthesis and structure of ion storage with Li-based ternary oxide cathodes. Compared to PBAs and polyanion compounds, layered oxides offer advantages such as facile synthesis, adjustable voltage range, high theoretical specific capacity, structural stability, and good sodium storage capacity ect [ , ].

However, NaxTMO2 cathodes face some challenges, including structural collapse, lower specific capacity, lower energy density, and reduced efficiency due to irreversible phase transitions [ ] and transition metal (TM) dissolution during electrochemical cycling [ , , ]. Other issues include air instability [ ], surface residual alkali [ ], and slow kinetics caused by complex phase transitions ect. Recent research efforts have focused on modifying layered oxides to address these issues [ ], such as (1) doping with specific elements to alter the charge density around Na+ and strengthen TM-O bonds to stabilize the layered structure and inhibit phase transitions; (2) constructing intercrystalline symbiotic structures to leverage the benefits of different crystalline phases and enhance structural stability [ , , , ]; and (3) applying various coating materials, including oxide coating, phosphate coating [ , ], and other coatings [ , ], to create an inert separator layer or fast-ionic conductor that mitigates anisotropic volume changes and side reactions between the cathode and electrolyte. For example, Qi et al. [ ] employed a ternary cathode gradient distribution strategy, coating MnOx on the surface of O3-NaNi1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3O2 using a liquid-phase method to reduce residual alkali and improve electrochemical properties such as capacity retention and rate capacity. Similarly, Liu et al. [ ] doped Ti and Mg as substitute elements for Co to obtain P2-Na0.67Mn0.53Ni0.30Mg0.085Ti0.085O2, thereby increasing the median discharge voltage from 3.21 V to 3.59 V and the energy density from 325 Wh kg−1 to 410 Wh g−1, which can not only promote the O compensation reaction but also inhibit the O2 loss at a high voltage of 4.25 V. Li et al. [ ] proposed constructing a NASICON-type NaTi2(PO4)3 nanoshell to inhibit side reactions and Mn3+ dissolution during cycling, thereby improving cycling stability and providing excellent Na+ diffusion paths and higher electronic conductivity. Also, Professor Zhao's team [ ] proposed the role of NaTi2(PO4)3 as a coating layer of O3-NaNi1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3O2, the NaTi2(PO4)3 coating layer can not only play a critical role in preventing the highly corrosive hydrofluoric acid (HF) attacks from decomposition of electrolyte and subsequent dissolution of the redox-active metal from the cathode particles but also expand the crystal spacing due to the partial doping of Ti4+, so as to stabilize the structure and promote the migration kinetics of Na+.

Based on the arrangement of the TM layer and the coordination environment of Na+, layered oxide cathodes are usually classified into two categories: O3-type and P2-type. In P2 phase, Na+ diffuses through adjacent prismatic sites with lower energy barriers, while in O3 phase, Na+ must pass through a tetrahedral site with higher energy to move from one octahedral site to the next, resulting in poorer Na+ diffusion kinetics and thus lower rate performance, which also impacts the cycling stability of the material. This phenomenon reflected in the design of pouch cell embodies high direct current resistance (DCR) and low energy efficiency, hindering large-scale application in energy storage systems. Previous studies have seldom focused specifically on the kinetic performance of materials, particularly in the field of layered oxides for SIBs. Rui et al. [ ] proposed a superior LT SIB composed of 3D porous Na3V2(PO4)3/C (NVP/C-F) and NaTi2(PO4)3/C foams (NTP/C-F) to develop high-performance SIBs at low temperature. The designed 3D interconnected porous foam structures demonstrate excellent electrolyte absorption ability and Na+ transport performance at low temperatures. Pang et al. [ ] found that appropriate Al doping improved the electrochemical stability of layered Mn-based oxides, demonstrating better electrode kinetics (with better Na+ diffusion coefficient). Kim et al. [ ] proposed that the kinetic hindrance of cobalt-free cathode materials is significantly influenced by current rate and electrode loading level, leading to a reduction in reversible specific capacity and cycling performance. Additionally, particle size and residual lithium content also affect Li+ diffusion kinetics. Thus, controlling particle size and employing strategies such as doping, coating, and washing to reduce residual lithium content are essential for enhancing the kinetic performance of materials.

Based on prior research, we found that poor kinetic performance of materials not only affects capacity and cycling stability but also leads to increased DCR and reduced energy efficiency in pouch cells, thereby hindering the further development and application of SIBs in the energy-storage system. Therefore, we propose to enhance the kinetic performance of O3-type NaNi1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3O2 layered oxides through topography control and component design (Fig. 1). On one hand, layered oxide cathodes typically exhibit a "flat sheet" morphology with crystals adhering to each other, this phenomenon adversely affects the kinetic performance of the material. To address the issue of improving the "flat sheet" morphology of layered oxides, we used Cu doping to reduce the exposure of inactive crystal plane (0 0 x) and promote de-flattening growth of crystals, thereby improving Na+ transport pathways and enhancing the kinetic performance of the material. Additionally, the Cu2+/Cu3+ redox electron pairs provide capacity compensation, slow down the phase transitions [ ] during electrochemical processes, and enhance structural stability. On the other hand, considering that cathode inevitably undergoes side reactions at the interface with the electrolyte, leading to the formation of an inert CEI layer, and the presence of surface residue, which hinders Na+ transport, we aim to suppress these interface side reactions by constructing an interface Na+ fast-ion conductor layer to improve Na+ transport kinetics. Therefore, we choose CoOOH coating strategy, where NaxCoO2 (0 < x ≤ 1) forms with residual sodium on the material surface exhibits good ion diffusion rates and high redox potential, not only suppressing interface side reactions but also promoting Na+ diffusion kinetics. The results show that although the two modification strategies we designed approach the problem from different angles, they ultimately both successfully improve the kinetic performance of O3-type NaNFMO. Verification results in pouch cells show that compared to NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co exhibit higher energy efficiency and better capacity retention under high current density conditions. This indicates that our modification strategies successfully improved the kinetic performance of O3-NaNFMO and provided new design ideas for the widespread and practical application of SIBs in the energy storage field.
Sections.name: Introduction

content: NaNi0.33Fe0.33Mn0.33O2 (NaNFMO) and Cu-doping NaNi0.31Fe0.33Mn0.33Cu0.02O2 (Cu-NaNFMO) were synthesized via solid-state reactions. The stoichiometric precursor Ni1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3(OH)2, anhydrous Na2CO3 (with a 3 % excess of Na), and nano CuO (Jinghuang Technology, 99.9 %) were mixed in a ball mill at 200 rpm for 5 h. The mixture was then calcined in a tube furnace at 1050 °C for 6 h followed by 900 °C for 12 h. After naturally cooling to approximately 100 °C, the materials were transferred to a glove box filled with argon (Ar) for grinding.

The Co coating NaNi0.33Fe0.33Mn0.33O2@Co (NaNFMO@Co) was also synthesized via solid-state reactions. Appropriate amounts of NaNFMO and CoOOH (5000 ppm, Yacheng New Energy) were mixed in a ball mill at 200 rpm for 1.5 h. The mixture was then transferred to a tube furnace and calcined in O2 at 550 °C for 4 h. Upon cooling to 100 °C, the material was quickly transferred to an Ar-filled glove box for grinding and storage.
content.name: Material preparations

content: The actual chemical composition of the three samples was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES). The structure of the samples was examined using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Discover). Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM, S-4800, Hitachi Co., Japan), High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL 2010F), and Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) were employed to investigate particle morphology, size, and element distribution. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PerkinElmer Co., USA) was utilized to determine the valence states of elements on the sample surfaces, with all peak positions corrected using the C 1s peak at 286.4 eV.
content.name: Material characterizations

content: CR2032 coin cells were assembled to test the electrochemical performance of the three samples. The active material, Super P, and PVDF were uniformly mixed at a mass ratio of 92:5:3 in an appropriate amount of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) solvent to prepare a slurry. This slurry was evenly coated on aluminum foil and dried in a vacuum oven at 100 °C for 12 h. The dried cathode was cut into 12 mm diameter discs (mass loading is about 5–6 mg cm−2). The coin cells were then assembled in a glove box using 1 M NaClO4 in PC (100 VOL%) with a 5.0 % FEC mixture as the electrolyte. Sodium metal served as the anode, and a glass fiber (Whatman GF/C 1822) was used as the separator. Charge-discharge tests were conducted at a constant current (1C = 140 mA g−1) on a battery test system (Land CT2001A, Wuhan Jinnuo Electronic Co., Ltd., China) between 2.0 and 4.0 V at room temperature. Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS, 100 kHz to 10 mHz) and Cyclic Voltammetry (CV, 2.0–4.0 V, Scan Rate = 0.1 mV s−1) were performed on an electrochemical workstation (Biologic VSP-300). The Galvanostatic Intermittent Titration Technique (GITT, Biologic VSP-300) was used to evaluate the Na+ diffusion coefficient (

D N a +), the current pulse was repeatedly applied at a current density of 0.1C for 10 min, and then the open circuit was relaxed for 1 h, and the above conditions were cycled until the voltage reached 4.0 V. Similar to the charging process, in the discharging process, the Coin cells were cycled at 0.1 C for an interval τ of 10 min, and then the open circuit was relaxed for 1 h, and the above conditions were cycled until the voltage reaches 2.0 V.

Assuming that the migration of Na+ in the cathode material follows Fick's second law, and the molar volume remains constant during charge and discharge, the apparent chemical diffusion coefficient of Na+ (
D N a +) can be calculated as:
D N a + = 4 π τ ( m B V m M B S ) 2 ( Δ E S Δ E τ ) 2 ( τ ≪ L 2 D )
In this formula,
m B is the mass of the active material,
V m is the molar volume,
M B is the molecular weight, S is the contact area between the electrode and the electrolyte,
Δ E S and
Δ E τ are respectively the steady-state voltage difference at rest and the total transient voltage difference after charging time τ, τ refers to the charging or discharging time.
content.name: Electrochemical measurements

content: Pouch cells were separately assembled using NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO, NaNFMO@Co cathodes, a hard carbon anode, and separator. The cathode slurry was coated onto Al foil in the ratio of 96 wt% active material, 2.7 wt% Super P, and 1.3 wt% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The hard carbon slurry was coated onto Al foil with 94.9 wt% HC, 3.9 wt% Super P, and 1.2 wt% sodium carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) in an aqueous solution. The CB content was 1.13, areal loading of the anode and cathode were 8.18 mg cm2 and 15.65 mg cm2, respectively. The cathode-separator-anode assembles were prepared, and then stacked with 9 cathode electrodes by 10 anode electrodes and packaged in a plastic-laminated aluminum pouch. Resultant pouch cell was dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 48 h before being moved into a glove box for injecting electrolyte. The size of prepared pouch cells was 83 × 4 × 63 mm (L × W × H). Prior to testing, the pouch cells were conditioned by pressing at 45 °C, charging with a CCCV process to 3.95 V at 0.1 C, then discharging to 2 V at 0.1 C, followed by cycling tests at a current density of 0.5 C.
content.name: Assembly and electrochemical test of pouch cell

content: The actual chemical compositions of NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO, and NaNFMO@Co were determined by ICP-AES, and the results are shown in Table 1, and the ratio of Ni/Fe/Mn/Cu was in line with the expected assumptions.
The X-ray diffraction (XRD) results, shown in Fig. 2a and b and Figs. S1a–b, indicated that all three samples exhibited an O3-type structure corresponding to R

3 ‾ m space group. The refinement parameters of the XRD results are provided in Table S1. Compared with NaNFMO, the a-axis spacing, unit cell volume, and the lengths of the Na-O and Na-TM bonds in Cu-NaNFMO increased, while the c-axis spacing and the length of the TM-O bonds decreased, which were due to the fact that Cu2+ substituted the TMn + site, and the Cu-O bond energy was greater than that of TM-O bond, so it was conducive to the (de)intercalation of Na+ in the electrochemical redox process. NaNFMO@Co still retained the O3-type structure, with no significant shifts in peak positions, indicating that the Co coating did not alter the structure of the material.

The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results reveal the valence states of elements in the samples. Fig. S2a displays the XPS spectra for Ni 2p. The binding energy at 854.2 and 871.6 eV correspond to Ni2+, [ ] while those at 855.7 and 873.3 eV correspond to Ni3+. Among the three samples, Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co have lower Ni3+ content and higher Ni2+ content compared to NaNFMO. Based on charge balance, it is inferred that Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co have higher Mn4+ content than NaNFMO, which increases the bond energy of Mn-O and stabilizes the structure. Additionally, fewer Jahn-Teller active Ni3+ reduce the likelihood of irreversible structural phase transitions [ , , ]. Fig. S2b shows the XPS spectra for Fe 2p. The peak at 710.1 eV corresponds to Fe2+, while those at 712.2 eV and 724.3 eV correspond to Fe3+, with a satellite peak at 718.3 eV. The results indicate the coexistence of Fe2+ and Fe3+, with Fe3+ being the predominant oxidation state [ , ]. The content of Fe3+ in Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co is higher than that in NaNFMO and the presence of Fe3+ exhibits an electron-withdrawing state, which increases the oxidation state of surrounding Mn ions, thereby suppressing the Jahn-Teller effect induced by Mn3+ [ ] and maintaining structural stability. Mn 2p spectra (Fig. S2c) shows the peaks at 641.6 and 653.3 eV correspond to Mn3+, while those at 643.0 and 655.5 eV correspond to Mn4+, and Mn4+ is predominant [ ]. Jahn-Teller distortion is primarily caused by Mn3+. Notably, compared to the original NaNFMO (48.35 %), the Mn4+ content in Cu-NaNFMO (56.19 %) and NaNFMO@Co (57.69 %) is increased while Mn3+ content is decreased, which helps to suppress Jahn-Teller distortion, maintain the reversible storage performance of Na+, and enhance structural stability. Fig. S3a presents the XPS survey spectra for the three samples. The XPS spectra for Cu 2p in Cu-NaNFMO are shown in Fig. S3b. The Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks are located at 933.2 and 953.0 eV, respectively, with a satellite peak at 945.0 eV, indicating that Cu shows +2 state [ ]. The XPS spectra for Co 2p in NaNFMO@Co are shown in Fig. S3c. Contrary to the general trend, the Co3+ peaks are observed at lower binding energies of 779.6 and 794.4 eV, while the Co2+ peaks are at higher binding energies of 781.6 and 795.9 eV, with a peak at 786.1 eV corresponding to the satellite peak. This indicates successful coating of Co [ , , ]. Additionally, the O 1s spectrum (Fig. 2d) reveals the peak at 528.8 eV attributed to lattice oxygen, which corresponds to TM-O; the peak at 530.8 eV assigned to oxygen species deposited on the material surface, such as Na2CO3 and the peak at 535.5 eV linked to oxygen in adsorbed water [ , , , ]. Analysis of the spectra indicates that the peaks related to adsorbed water in Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co are smaller compared to those in NaNFMO, suggesting their better air stability. The C 1s spectrum (Fig. 2c) exhibits peaks representing various carbon species: the peak at 284.3 eV is attributed to C-C/C=O, and the peak at 289.1 eV is associated with -C-C=O [ , , , , ]. These analyses above indicate Cu doping and Co coating reduce residual alkali content.

Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) images (Fig. 3a–b, 3d-e, and Figs. S4a–d) revealed that Cu-NaNFMO had a more rounded morphology and uniform dispersion compared to the flattened morphology of pristine NaNFMO. EDS results (Fig. 3g and h) confirmed uniform distribution of Ni/Fe/Mn/Cu without significant enrichment. Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) images (Fig. 3c and f) showed clear layered structures in both NaNFMO and Cu-NaNFMO, with the (1 0 2) crystal plane spacing increasing from 0.236 nm to 0.249 nm after Cu doping, consistent with the XRD results.

Due to the lower surface energy of the inactive crystal plane (0 0 x) than the active crystal plane (1 0 x), the inactive side (0 0 x) was always preferentially developed during the growth process, resulting in the crystals tend to grow flat and easily stick together. We utilized the Quantum Espresso (QE) software package to fine-tune the crystal structure and conduct energy calculations before and after Cu doping [ ]. In this process, we employed the Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) function under the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) to handle exchange-related contributions [ ]. The interaction between core and valence electrons was using optimized norm-conserving Vanderbilt (ONCV) pseudopotentials [ , ]. To ensure accuracy, we set cutoffs for the wavefunctions and charge density at 120 Ry and 480 Ry, respectively. For the (0 0 3) crystal plane, we embarked on an initial structural optimization journey using a 9 × 9 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid, relaxing until the force on every atom dwindled to less than 10−3 Ry/Bohr. After this optimization, we introduced a 15 Å vacuum layer on the (0 0 3) crystal plane and calculated. The surface energy (E) of this crystal plane was derived from the following equation:E = E1 - N × E2where E1 represents the energy of the unit cell, E2 symbolizes the energy of the slab, and N stands for the number of atoms in the slab. The treatment for the (1 0 4) crystal plane was essentially similar. VESTA is used for visualization processing [ ].

The results showed that Cu doping increased the surface energy of the inactive (0 0 3) plane from 0.92 J m−2 to 1.36 J m−2, and decreased the active (1 0 4) plane energy from 1.19 J m−2 to 0.89 J m−2 (Fig. 3i and j). This indicated inhibited growth of the (0 0 3) plane and promoted growth of the (1 0 4) plane, reducing mutual adhesion and enhancing crystal kinetics. These findings correspond to the SEM results showing improved crystal morphology with Cu doping.
content.name: Effect of Cu doping on surface energy

content: Electrochemical performance tests were conducted on assembled coin cells at a voltage of 2.0–4.0 V. Cu-NaNFMO exhibited higher coulombic efficiency, better capacity retention after 100 cycles, and slower capacity decay compared to NaNFMO (Fig. 4a). The initial charge-discharge curves (Fig. 4b) indicated higher specific capacity and smoother curves for Cu-NaNFMO, attributable to the participation of Cu2+/Cu3+ redox pairs providing additional capacity and mitigating irreversible phase transitions during redox processes. After experiencing a current density of 0.1 C, 0.2 C, 0.5 C, 1 C, 5 C and then returning to 0.1 C (Figs. 4c and 1 C = 140 mA g−1), Cu-NaNFMO could achieve a capacity recovery rate of 98.42 %, while NaNFMO was only 96.77 %, indicating that Cu-NaNFMO could maintain a higher capacity at a higher current density. Maintaining a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1, Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) diagram (Fig. 4d and e) showed that the redox peak of Cu-NaNFMO at 3.15/2.85 V was sharper and higher and the difference was smaller, indicating that Cu-NaNFMO had more storage energy capacity at low voltage and better reversibility during electrochemical cycling.

The Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) of NaNFMO and Cu-NaNFMO were shown in Fig. 4g–h, and Fig. S5 shows the equivalent circuit. The semicircle at high-frequency represented the membrane impedance (Rf), and the semicircle at low-frequency represented the charge transfer impedance (Rct), both were increased with the cycles, but the impedance of Cu-NaNFMO was much smaller than that of NaNFMO. Fig. S6a shows a schematic illustration of the single-step GITT process. In this context, Ohmic polarization refers to the voltage difference between the initial charging voltage and the previous relaxation voltage during the relaxation process. Voltage polarization is defined as the difference between the charging termination voltage and the equilibrium voltage at the end of the next relaxation process. The magnitudes of Voltage polarization and Ohmic polarization directly reflect the rate of Na+ deintercalation. Comparing the GITT results, as shown in Figs. S6b and S6c, the Na+ diffusion coefficients (
D N a +) for NaNFMO and Cu-NaNFMO both fall within the magnitude range of 10−11 to 10−9 cm2 s−1. Notably, Cu-NaNFMO exhibits a higher DNa⁺ (Fig. 4f), indicating better kinetic performance.
content.name: Improvement of electrochemical properties by Cu doping
Cu-doped layered oxide cathode

content: SEM results (Fig. 5a and b and Figs. S4e–f) indicated that the morphology of NaNFMO did not significantly change after Co coating, although the edges and corners were slightly passivated. TEM images (Fig. 5c) showed that the coating layer was relatively homogeneous, with a thickness of about 4–6 nm. EDS results (Fig. 5d) confirmed an even distribution of Ni, Fe, Mn, and Co elements, indicating a uniform Co coating.

Effects of Co coating on the electrochemical properties. The initial cycle charge-discharge curves for NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co (Fig. 6a) demonstrated that NaNFMO@Co exhibited a higher specific capacity and a smoother electrochemical curve. This improvement could be attributed to high-temperature calcination under O2, which compensates for structural damage and oxygen loss, partially recovering capacity. Additionally, NaNFMO@Co showed reduced polarization, indicating decreased residual alkali. Fig. 6b shows that NaNFMO@Co had a capacity retention rate of 66.19 % after 100 cycles, significantly higher than 58.13 % of the NaNFMO. At the same time, the first cycle coulombic efficiency (CE) of NaNFMO@Co also improved from 90.69 % to 93.57 %, enhancing the energy efficiency of the material.

Rate performance data (Fig. 6c) revealed that NaNFMO@Co achieved a 97.56 % capacity recovery after cycling at a high current of 5 C and returning to a low current of 0.1 C (1 C = 140 mA g−1), indicating smoother Na+ deintercalation and improved kinetics after Co coating. The overall resistance of the NaNFMO@Co cathode was lower than that of NaNFMO (Fig. 4, Fig. 6g). The CV curves (Fig. 6d) compared the redox behavior of NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1, with the redox peak at 3.15/2.85 V representing the Ni2+/Ni3+ redox pair [ ]. The peaks of NaNFMO@Co were sharper, higher, and had a smaller gap, indicating better electrochemical reversibility. GITT results (Fig. 6e and f) showed that NaNFMO@Co maintained
D N a + in the order of 10−11 to 10−9, reflecting superior kinetic performance.
content.name: CoOOH coating layered oxide cathode

content: Residual alkali is a significant issue for SIBs cathodes. Surface residual sodium reacts with H2O and CO2 in the air, forming NaOH and Na2CO3 [ ], while lattice sodium can be exchanged by protons H, leading to lattice destruction and structural collapse. Surface residual sodium further reacts with the electrolyte, evolving gas during electrochemical cycles and increasing battery safety risks. These residues also form surface resistance compounds, hindering Na+ deintercalation and degrading electrochemical performance. Additionally, the strong alkalinity of residual sodium can cause defluoridation of the PVDF binder in the slurry, leading to gelation and flocculation during slurry coating [ ]. Residual alkali content results (Fig. S7a) showed that Cu doping improved air stability of the sample and reduced structural Na + substitution by H2O, thus lowering residual alkali. NaNFMO@Co exhibited a significant reduction in residual alkali, likely due to the reaction between Co and residual Na2CO3 forming NaxCoO2, which consumes residual alkali. NaxCoO2 also serves as an excellent Na + transport medium, improving the kinetics of Na+. XRD analysis (Fig. S7b) confirmed the formation of Na0.6CoO2 from calcining an equal molar mixture of Na2CO3 and CoOOH at 550 °C for 4 h in O2, proving that CoOOH reacts with surface residual alkali after Co coating, reducing polarization and enhancing kinetics of the material.
content.name: Residual alkali

content: Pouch cells were assembled using NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO, and NaNFMO@Co cathods, and their cycling curves were shown in Fig. 7a. During 500 cycles, Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co demonstrated greater stability, with capacity retention rates of 97.98 % and 99.22 %, respectively, higher than that of NaNFMO (94.71 %). The initial charge-discharge curves (Fig. 7b) revealed that Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co had initial capacities of 1290 mAh and 1289 mAh, respectively, higher than that of NaNFMO (1286 mAh), and the first two had a higher voltage plateau. Fig. 7c shows that NaNFMO@Co exhibited the best rate performance, followed by Cu-NaNFMO, and NaNFMO last. Furthermore, Fig. 7d indicates that the energy efficiency of Cu-NaNFMO and NNFMO@Co is 94 % and 95.7 % at 0.5 C respectively, which is greater than that of NaNFMO (93.3 %). This phenomenon suggests that, under equivalent discharge conditions, Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co utilize energy more effectively, contributing to reduced electricity costs and enhanced energy efficiency. Additionally, NaNFMO@Co had a DCR of 51.3 mΩ, significantly lower than that of NaNFMO (63.3 mΩ), validating the effectiveness of Co coating in enhancing material kinetics. The DCR of Cu-NaNFMO was 66.61 mΩ, higher than NaNFMO's 63.3 mΩ, which is attributed to the larger single crystal size due to Cu doping, slightly raising the DCR but overall improving energy efficiency. In summary, Cu doping and Co coating strategies significantly enhanced the performance metrics of the pouch cells, demonstrating the feasibility of our modification strategy.
content.name: Pouch cells data validation

Sections.name: Results and discussion

content: O3-NaNFMO was synthesized via a solid-state reaction, and the O3-type Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co were successfully obtained through Cu doping and Co coating strategies. Cu doping improved the "flat sheet" morphology of the layered oxide, formed strong Cu-O bonds, stabilized the layered structure, and expanded the diffusion paths of Na+. The Co coating reacted with residual sodium on the surface to produce the Na+ fast ionic conductor NaxCoO2, thereby promoting the migration of Na+. Both strategies significantly enhanced the kinetic performance of pristine NaNFMO. Additionally, the energy efficiency of pouch cells made from Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co was markedly improved.

As discussed above, the capacity of NaNFMO was increased by approximately 4–5 mAh g−1, the capacity retention after 100 cycles was improved by about 10 %, and electrochemical reversibility was significantly enhanced. Furthermore, Cu doping and Co coating effectively inhibited the anisotropic volume changes of pristine NaNFMO during charging and discharging process, thereby stabilizing the structure.

In summary, our work has significantly improved the kinetics and electrochemical performance of layered oxides, providing a feasible method for the practical application and promotion of layered oxides in SIBs.
Sections.name: Conclusion

content: Xue Wen: Writing – original draft, Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation, Conceptualization. Haoyang Yuan: Methodology, Investigation. Yite Liu: Investigation. Tao Huang: Writing – review & editing, Visualization, Resources, Methodology. Aishui Yu: Writing – review & editing, Visualization, Resources, Project administration, Funding acquisition.
Sections.name: CRediT authorship contribution statement

content: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
Sections.name: Declaration of competing interest

Title: Topography control and component design strategies to enhance electrochemical performance of O3-Type cathode materials for Sodium-ion batteries
